orientation.purpose: Welcome learners, explain how the CSIR training flows from orientation to certificate, and set expectations for role-based branching.
orientation.gate: I understand the modules, role tailoring, and that I must complete each step in order to unlock the certificate.

topics.title: Course objectives
topics.detail: Learn the CSIR incident lifecycle, your role responsibilities, and how to document/report incidents accurately.

topics.title: Estimated time & flow
topics.detail: Eight modules (5–10 minutes each) with inline knowledge checks, a scenario lab, and a final assessment.

topics.title: Progress & persistence
topics.detail: Navigation and completion state are saved locally; resume anytime with your selected role.

topics.title: Certificate & evidence
topics.detail: Certificate unlocks after all required modules and the final quiz—use it as completion evidence.

points.title: Preparation (CSIR Plan 8.1)
points.detail: Confirm tools, backups, contacts, and forensics readiness; rehearse team roles before incidents.

points.title: Identification & Analysis
points.detail: Validate anomalies, classify Cyber Event vs. Incident vs. Attempt, and check Appendix C for reportability.

points.title: Containment & Communications
points.detail: Isolate affected systems, change credentials, and notify SOC/IMT/leadership per the communications matrix.

points.title: Recovery (CSIR Plan 8.5)
points.detail: Restore from clean backups or rebuild, verify systems are clean, and obtain leadership approval to return to service.

points.title: Follow-Up & Reporting
points.detail: Log lessons learned, update the CSIR Plan, and complete DOE-417 reporting to E-ISAC/CISA within required timelines.

check.question: A malware alert is validated on a control center HMI. It is contained within 15 minutes with no outage. How should it be classified?
options: Reportable Cyber Security Incident that must be reported within 1 hour
Attempt to Compromise that is documented and reported by end of next business day
Not an event; no action required
Only a local ticket is needed
check.rationale: The alert was contained before impact; Appendix C treats this as an Attempt to Compromise requiring notification by the end of the next business day.
check.success: Correct—reportability clocks start now. Capture evidence and keep Compliance looped in.

plan.lead: Module 3 walks through the CSIR workflow from preparation to follow-up with communications and reporting checkpoints.

steps.title: Preparation
steps.detail: Maintain contact lists, IMT on-call rotation, imaging kits, clean backups, and baselines; rehearse roles and timers.
steps.audit: Show readiness evidence: tool checks, role rosters, and forensics readiness notes.

steps.title: Identification & Analysis
steps.detail: Validate indicators, classify using Appendix C, and decide if the event is reportable or an attempt.
steps.audit: Record who validated, time stamps, and decision on reportability.

steps.title: Containment & Response
steps.detail: Isolate systems, change credentials, notify SOC/IMT, and coordinate with Incident Commander for decisions.
steps.audit: Evidence of containment steps, communication logs, and approvals.

steps.title: Recovery & Return to Service
steps.detail: Restore from trusted backups or rebuild, run validation scans, and gain leadership approval before going live.
steps.audit: Recovery plan, clean scan results, and documented approval to return to service.

steps.title: Follow-Up & Reporting
steps.detail: Hold lessons learned, update the CSIR Plan, and complete DOE-417 submission to E-ISAC/CISA within the deadline.
steps.audit: Completed DOE-417, evidence logs, and recorded corrective actions.

plan.note: Every phase includes a communication checkpoint and evidence expectation—capture who acted, when, and where artifacts are stored.

links.label: SCL OT CSIR Plan (Appendix B & C excerpts)

notes: Keep local copies of procedures, DOE-417 templates, and checklists for disconnected operations.
Validate time sources before drills and audits to align all logs.
Store certificates and incident artifacts in the evidence binder with timestamped filenames.

questions.prompt: You validated malware on an HMI with no outage. What should the Incident Commander decide?
options: Declare a full Reportable Cyber Security Incident
Classify as an Attempt to Compromise and start the end-of-next-business-day reporting clock
Close the alert without documentation
Wait for leadership to return
questions.audit: Classification drives DOE-417 timing and evidence handling.

questions.prompt: Containment isolated the affected server. Who must be notified first based on the communications matrix?
options: The vendor support desk
Your peer in another department
SOC/Incident Commander with timestamps
Only the person who found it
questions.audit: Communications must follow the documented matrix with time-stamped proof.

questions.prompt: Recovery is complete after restoring from backup. What must the Technical Responder and Incident Commander do before returning to service?
options: Declare victory immediately
Verify clean state with scans and get leadership approval to go live
Ask the vendor to send a note
Skip documentation to save time
questions.audit: Return-to-service requires validation evidence and approval.

questions.prompt: A phishing simulation was reported by General Staff. What should Compliance capture?
options: Nothing—it was a simulation
A short log entry noting it was an Attempt to Compromise with timestamps
Full DOE-417 report
Only verbal confirmation
questions.audit: Even simulations reinforce reporting discipline and evidence habits.
